article.title: The MUSE Hubble Ultra Deep Field Survey. IX. Evolution of galaxy merger fraction since z 6

multiple_choice_question.text: What does Figure 1 illustrate about the spectroscopic redshift distribution of galaxies in the MUSE data?
choices: There are significantly more galaxies observed at redshift 2 than at redshift 3.
The UDF-Mosaic data shows a peak at a redshift of approximately 1.
The HDF-S data shows the highest number of galaxies at a redshift of approximately 5.
The udf-10 data has a relatively even distribution of galaxies across all redshifts.

multiple_choice_question.text: What can be concluded from Figure 2 about the redshift distribution of galaxy close pairs?
choices: Major close pairs are more commonly found at higher redshifts (z > 4).
The UDF-Mosaic data shows a significant peak in the number of major close pairs at a redshift of approximately 2.
The HDF-S data contributes the most to the total number of major close pairs observed.
The number of major close pairs generally increases with redshift up to z â‰ˆ 3.

multiple_choice_question.text: What does Figure 6 tell us about the stellar mass ratio of close pairs identified in the MUSE deep fields?
choices: The majority of close pairs have a mass ratio greater than 1:4 at all redshifts.
Close pairs with lower mass ratios are more common at higher redshifts.
There is a clear trend of increasing mass ratio with increasing redshift.
The mass ratio of close pairs does not seem to be correlated with the redshift.

multiple_choice_question.text: Formula (3) describes the major merger fraction, fMM(zr), for a given redshift bin zr. What does the term C1 in this formula account for?
choices: The influence of cosmic variance on the observed number of close pairs.
The incompleteness of the spectroscopic redshift catalogue.
The missing companions due to the limited spatial resolution of the observations.
The weighting factor applied to pairs with different levels of redshift confidence.
